summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 between Jill Greenfield, a partner at Fieldfisher law firm, and Assistant United States Attorneys from the Southern District of New York. The emails discuss scheduling a videoconference or meeting between the prosecutors and Greenfield's client, who is presumably a witness or person of interest in the Epstein investigation, to discuss her questions and concerns. The correspondence highlights logistical challenges due to COVID-19 travel restrictions.

persons.name: Jill Greenfield
persons.context: Attorney communicating with US Attorneys to schedule a meeting between them and her client regarding the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Prosecutor from the Southern District of New York corresponding with Jill Greenfield about scheduling a meeting with Greenfield's client.

connections.description: Attorney for a client communicating with a prosecutor to arrange a discussion regarding the Epstein investigation.

Prosecutor seeking to meet with Greenfield's client as part of the ongoing Epstein investigation.

events.title: Client Agrees to Speak with Prosecutors
events.description: Jill Greenfield informs prosecutors that her client is willing to speak with them to discuss matters related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Proposed Meeting Dates
events.description: Prosecutors propose specific dates in October 2020 (14th-16th or 20th-22nd) for a potential three-day meeting with Jill Greenfield's client, pending internal approvals.

keyFacts: In September 2020, a client of attorney Jill Greenfield was willing to speak with US Attorneys from the SDNY about the Epstein investigation.
The proposed communication was to involve the client asking prosecutors 'how you would manage this,' indicating she had concerns or conditions.
Logistical planning was complicated by COVID-19, as government employee travel was potentially prohibited, making a videoconference the likely format.
The prosecutors were seeking internal approvals for the meeting and needed to propose specific dates to move the approval process forward.
The email chain shows an active investigative dialogue between a witness's counsel and the prosecution team years after Epstein's arrest and death.
